feedback.Physical object: Included — A tangible mechanical device composed of gears, hands, and casing.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Included — Designed and constructed by humans.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — Mechanisms are based on physics and engineering, not biology.
feedback.Fixed/static: Included — Generally stationary and not meant to be moved during operation.
feedback.Structural: Included — Its internal operation depends on precise physical structure (gears, springs, escapement).
feedback.Perceptible: Included — Meant to be seen and/or heard (e.g., ticking or chimes).
feedback.Material form: Included — Made from durable, manufactured materials (metal, glass, etc.).
feedback.Passive: Excluded — Actively moves through internal mechanical energy.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Designed to keep and display time.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Included — Shows time visually and sometimes audibly.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Included — Internal escapement mechanism regulates consistent time intervals.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Included — Winding modifies spring tension; mechanisms release energy over time.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — Users observe it but do not interact with it functionally.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Included — May synchronize or be integrated into broader timekeeping or architectural systems.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — Requires periodic winding or external energy input.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — Timekeeping is often helpful but not mission-critical in most settings.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Excluded — Not inherently symbolic or abstract.
feedback.Communicative: Excluded — Displays time but not in a communicative or coded way.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Included — Internally operates on consistent, rule-based mechanical logic.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Excluded — Not composed of conceptual modules, only mechanical parts.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Excluded — It provides information but doesn’t prescribe behavior.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — Does not reflect on itself or represent abstract systems.
feedback.Temporal: Included — Core function is to represent and track time.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Excluded — Operates consistently regardless of symbolic or abstract context.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Excluded — Functionally universal, not constructed by cultural consensus.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Excluded — Exists across many systems but not semantically defined by any one.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Excluded — Not tied to personal or social roles.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Excluded — Some clocks are certified, but the concept isn’t intrinsically governed.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Excluded — Can be taught, but this is not central to its form.
feedback.Visible: Included — Deliberately designed to be viewed (often publicly).
feedback.Context-sensitive: Excluded — Displays absolute time, not contextually altered.
feedback.Widely known: Included — Clocks are globally recognized and ubiquitous.

encoding_notes: This encoding reflects the mechanical clock as a traditional timekeeping apparatus, emphasizing its engineered structure, functional logic, and universal recognizability. Abstract traits are limited to its time-based logic, while social traits are included only when visually and culturally universal. It excludes interaction and autonomy due to its passive user interface and reliance on manual winding.
